Controversy Explanation: TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, petitioned the university president to disinvite Jill-Levine from a summit on campus, hosted by James Martin, because of Martin's views on child transition and homosexuality, and because Jill-Levine is listed as a donor to Planned Parenthood and has argued that the Bible never condemned homosexuality.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, petitioned the university president to disinvite McNichols from a summit on campus, hosted by James Martin, because of Martin's views on child transition and homosexuality, and because of McNichols' "blasphemous 'art'" including a piece titled "AIDS Crucifixion."
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, petitioned the university president to disinvite Martin from hosting a summit on campus because of Martin's views on child transition and homosexuality.
Public Response: None.

Source(s): Activist(s), Alumni, Politician(s), Student Group(s), Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: The campus chapter of Uncensored America hosted a "roast" of Vice President, and current Democratic nominee for President, Kamala Harris and invited McInnes (and Milo Yiannopolous) to be the "roastmasters." Students, student groups, alumni, local politicians and the NAACP opposed the "roast" and demanded the university cancel the event because of McInnes' (and Yiannopolous') past history of "racism," "bigotry," "misogyny," and "white nationalism." The "roast" was held successfully.
Public Response: Honors.  The university issued an official statement: "A hallmark of a college education is exposure to opinions and ideas that may be far from your own. In addition to the typical tabling events and campus speakers that students may find interesting or challenging, the election occurring this semester also offers opportunities for students to become civically engaged. Civic engagement helps students become responsible, educated citizens in local, national and global communities.  Like other public institutions, USC allows recognized student groups to invite speakers of their choosing to campus — even ones with whom many in our community would strongly disagree. These appearances in no way represent an endorsement by the university of any individual speaker’s message but should be viewed as our commitment to allowing constitutionally protected speech on campus. This longstanding tradition has resulted in a variety of campus speakers representing all sides of political and ethical thought — to see some of the diversity of upcoming events, visit our campus calendar."  Full statement: https://www.sc.edu/uofsc/announcements/posts/2024/08/message-to-students-regarding-speakers-on-campus.php

School: Brooklyn College, City University of New York
Controversy Explanation: Malloy, the lead American negotiator on the Iran nuclear deal, was scheduled to speak at a Jewish Currents all day event. Two weeks before the event the college informed Jewish Currents about a leak in the main auditorium, one of the buidlings reserved, and canceled the entire event, including Malloy's speech.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  A college spokesperson said that there were: "no political considerations"" involved in the cancellation and that ""the theater’s ceiling was compromised from a roof leak, undermining the safety of its occupancy."

School: Brooklyn College, City University of New York
Controversy Explanation: Albanese, the United Nations special rapporteur on the occupied Palestinian territories, was scheduled to speak at a Jewish Currents all day event. Two weeks before the event the college informed Jewish Currents about a leak in the main auditorium, one of the buidlings reserved, and canceled the entire event, including Albanese's speech.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  A college spokesperson said that there were: "no political considerations"" involved in the cancellation and that ""the theater’s ceiling was compromised from a roof leak, undermining the safety of its occupancy."

School: Brooklyn College, City University of New York
Controversy Explanation: Jewish Currents, an off-campus magazine, arranged to use multiple buildings at the college for a day long event featuring panel discussion and performances about politics and culture. Two weeks before the event the college informed Jewish Currents about a leak in the main auditorium, one of the buildings reserved, and canceled the entire event.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  A college spokesperson said that there were: "no political considerations"" involved in the cancellation and that ""the theater’s ceiling was compromised from a roof leak, undermining the safety of its occupancy."

Controversy Explanation: The campus chapter of the Young American Foundation and the College Republicans invited Krikorian, the Executive Director of the Center for Immigration Studies, to campus for a speech about immigration followed by a Q&A. Less than ten minutes into Krikorian's speech masked protestors in the audience used their phones to set off alarms and other sounds. Some protesters began shouting over Krikorian demanding he address their questions and calling him a "racist" and a "bigot" as Krikorian contiued speaking. Associate Vice Provost for Student Engagement and Dean of Students asked the protestors to demnstrate against Krikorian's speech in a less disruptive manner, but this request was refused. Protestors also used stink sprays to fill the room with an unpleasant odor. Eventually YAF decided to end the event early so Krikorian could speak with interested students outside the room.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Gender, Immigration, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Political Views, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Multiple student groups, including the Young Democratic Socialists of America and MT Lambda, issued statements on social media opposing Pence's invitation to speak on Consitution Day at the Honors College on campus. YDS and MT Lambda objected to Pence because of his "authoritarian" and "anti-democratic" views, his ties to pro-Israel individuals and groups, for being "a puppet of big oil and the military-industrial complex," his work on Project 2025, his support for voter ID laws, his opposition to same-sex marriage, his support for the "Don't Say Gay" law, and his "signaled" support for the overturning of Roe v. Wad,  Chevron, and extensive measures targeting the queer community." Pence spoke successfully.
Public Response: Honors.  The university president said: "MTSU throughout the years has hosted speakers representing a wide spectrum of beliefs, perspectives and points of view. I have long held that providing a welcoming environment for the free expression of ideas is essential for preparing students to become successful scholars, engaged citizens and well-rounded human beings."

Controversy Explanation: During a Board of Regents meeting, protestors affiliated with UW Divest for Palestine shouted down speakers during the public comment period of a proposal to form a committee to consider university divestment from "weapons comapnies" that do business with Israel. Protesters were warned by the board multiple times that the room would be cleared if the disruption continued. The board ultimately decided to adjourn the meeting "after disruptions made orderly conduct of the meeting impossible."
Public Response: Neutral.  In a joint statement the board's outgoing chair and incoming chair said: "Speakers addressing labor issues and those calling for divestment from Israel had spoken without interruption, but when Jewish speakers opposed to divestment and concerned about antisemitism on campus began their comments, protestors repeatedly interrupted and shouted them down. Despite repeated warnings to stop and clear the room, protesters continued their chants to shut down the meeting.""  They further condemned the protesters’ actions as “antithetical to free dialogue and disrespectful of other UW community members.”

Controversy Explanation: Lowry was scheduled to visit the school as a part of the Indiana State University Speaker Series. A few weeks before the event Lowry appeared on the Megyn Kelly Show and admittedly mispronounced the word migrants. Crtics allege Lowry was about to say a racial slur but caught himself in time. Administrators canceled Lowry's appearance on "the advice of the university's public safety officials regarding campus and community safety concerns..."
Public Response: Disingenuous.  The university said: "It is important to stress that this cancellation is not intended to limit our neutrality on different political viewpoints. Indiana State University remains firmly committed to fostering intellectual diversity and encouraging the respectful exchange of ideas from multiple perspectives."

Controversy Explanation: During Cunningham's inaguration speech as the 18th president of the university the crowd began chanting "Disclose, divest! We will not stop, we will not rest!" and "Free Free Palestine! Free Free Palestine!" drowning out Cunningham. The chanting continued as other speakers attempted to calm the crown down. A university spokesperson then threatened the protesters with legal action and academic suspension. The protesters took almost five minutes to exit the venue. Cunningham resumed her speech and completed it successfully.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: The law school chapter of the Federalist Society invited Kleinfeld, a professor of law at George Mason University, and Simcha Rothman a member of Israel's parliament to speak on campus at an event titled Restoring Democracy: The Debate Over Judicial Reform in Israel. Before the event started, UnXeptable, a group of Israeli expats, began shouting at Rothman and arguing with him in Hebrew over his support for a bill that would give the Knesset more oversight of Israel’s judicial system. Then when the event began, pro-Palestinian protesters began shouting at Rothman and also began louldy arguing with the members of UnXetable. Security removed Rothman from the auditorium and those in attendance were informed that he would answer questions via Zoom.
Public Response: Honors.  The dean of the law school condemned the actions of the protesters in an email to law school students, faculty and staff:  “What occurred today in the Law School is unacceptable in an academic community,” Chemerinsky wrote of Tuesday’s event. “We must be a place where all ideas and views can be expressed. There is no right to disrupt a speaker.”  The dean also said that if any students participated in the disruption, they would face “disciplinary proceedings.”"

Controversy Explanation: The law school chapter of the Federalist Society invited Rothman, a member of Israel's parliament, (and Joshua Kleinfeld) to speak on campus at an event titled Restoring Democracy: The Debate Over Judicial Reform in Israel. Before the event started, UnXeptable, a group of Israeli expats, began shouting at Rothman and arguing with him in Hebrew over his support for a bill that would give the Knesset more oversight of Israel’s judicial system. Then when the event began, pro-Palestinian protesters began shouting at Rothman and also began louldy arguing with the members of UnXetable. Security removed Rothman from the auditorium and those in attendance were informed that he would answer questions via Zoom.
Public Response: Honors.  Berkeley Law dean Erwin Chemerinsky strongly condemned the actions of the protesters in an email to law school students, faculty and staff:  “What occurred today in the Law School is unacceptable in an academic community,” Chemerinsky wrote of Tuesday’s event. “We must be a place where all ideas and views can be expressed. There is no right to disrupt a speaker.”  Chemerinsky said that if any students participated in the disruption, they would face “disciplinary proceedings.”"

Controversy Explanation: The university’s Humanities Institute, Department of History, Department of Politics & International Affairs, Middle East South Asian Studies Program, and the National Endowment for the Humanities scheduled an event featuring Abdulhadi, a professor and founding director of the Arab and Muslim Ethnicities and Diasporas Studies Program at San Francisco State University, for October 7, 2024. Abdulhadi's scheuled talk was titled “One Year Since al-Aqsa Flood: Reflections on a Year of Genocide and Resistance.” A student initiated petition, that garnered over 8,500 signatures, demanded the university rescind Abdulhadi's invitation because Abdulhadi has "publicly threatened Jewish students" and "publicly supported and celebrated terrorists." The university revoked Abdulhadi's invitation to speak on campus.
Public Response: Condemn Expression.  In a joint statement emailed to the campus community the university president and provost said: "We have also made the conscious decision not to host events on this day that are inherently contentious and stand to stoke division in our campus community. Thus, we have informed the academic units sponsoring Dr. Rabab Abdulhadi’s campus lecture on October 7 that it cannot take place. We are living in complex times, and yet we remain hopeful about the future because of this caring community and our shared mission to serve humanity."

Controversy Explanation: Lâm, the president of Vietnam and the Communist Party of Vietnam’s general secretary, was invited by the university to speak at the its annual World Leaders Forum. A member Congress, representing a district in California, sent a letter to the university's interim president  demanding they revoke Lâm's invitation because he is "chiefly responsible for the ongoing repression of the Vietnamese people" and becauuse the representiative's district is almost 20% Vietnamese. The university did not respond to the letter and Lâm spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral.  A university spokesperson said: "Columbia World Leaders Forum invites influential figures from across the globe to engage with our University community, in support of the institution’s larger academic mission to teach, create, and advance knowledge. That mission is grounded in a fundamental commitment to free expression, open inquiry, and vigorous debate. An invitation to speak at an event is neither a validation nor an endorsement of any individual speaker’s views. The program includes ample time for students to question the speakers, challenge their records, and address them with other views."

Controversy Explanation: The campus chapter of Turning Point USA invited Kirk to appear at a tabling event on campus as part of Kirk's "You're Being Brainwashed Tour." About a week prior to the event the Student Committee for Defense and Solidarity started a petition demanding the university deny Kirk access to campus. Kirk appeared at the event but was unable to deliver a planned speech because TPUSA violated university policy by using amplified sound. Kirk (and Jack Posobiec) remained on campus and continued to conversations with several students attending the event.
Public Response: Neutral.  A University spokesperson said: "The requested activity by the student chapter of Turning Point USA was to set up a table to distribute information, which was approved. There was no request made nor did the group follow University policy for having a speaker. Regardless, Charlie Kirk’s presence on campus is permitted under the First Amendment as well as under Penn State Policy AD 51 “Use of Outdoor Areas for Expressive Activities. Under AD51, however, there are requirements that must be followed including the prohibition of the use of sound amplification equipment between 8 a.m. and 6 p.m. The student leaders of Turning Point USA were aware of this limitation and were explicitly reminded this morning before their event began that amplification was not permitted. After the event started, the group was asked to stop using amplification due to its violation of AD 51, which the University must enforce uniformly across events and groups. As a strong supporter of free speech, the University did not ask the group to cease activities nor to stop the event. It could have gone on without amplification, as was seen when another speaker did continue the Turning Point USA event after sound amplification was stopped."

Controversy Explanation: The campus chapter of Turning Point USA invited Charlie Kirk to appear at a tabling event on campus as part of Kirk's "You're Being Brainwashed Tour," Posobiec joined Kirk on this stop of the tour. About a week prior to the event the Student Committee for Defense and Solidarity started a petition demanding the university deny Kirk access to campus. Kirk appeared at the event but was unable to deliver a planned speech because TPUSA violated university policy by using amplified sound. Posobiec and Kirk remained on campus and continued to conversations with several students attending the event.
Public Response: Neutral.  A University spokesperson said: "The requested activity by the student chapter of Turning Point USA was to set up a table to distribute information, which was approved. There was no request made nor did the group follow University policy for having a speaker. Regardless, Charlie Kirk’s presence on campus is permitted under the First Amendment as well as under Penn State Policy AD 51 “Use of Outdoor Areas for Expressive Activities. Under AD51, however, there are requirements that must be followed including the prohibition of the use of sound amplification equipment between 8 a.m. and 6 p.m. The student leaders of Turning Point USA were aware of this limitation and were explicitly reminded this morning before their event began that amplification was not permitted. After the event started, the group was asked to stop using amplification due to its violation of AD 51, which the University must enforce uniformly across events and groups. As a strong supporter of free speech, the University did not ask the group to cease activities nor to stop the event. It could have gone on without amplification, as was seen when another speaker did continue the Turning Point USA event after sound amplification was stopped."

Controversy Explanation: The human rights, economics and anthropology departments invited Albanese, a United Nations official, to campus. Albanese's invititation was opposed by UN Watch, a nonprofit supportive of Israel, because Albanese has accused Israel of committing "genocide" in Gaza and allegedely made other antisemitic remarks, and urged Barnard to rescind the invitation. Barnard refused and Albanese spoke successfully on campus.
Public Response: Neutral. A college spokesperson said: "Barnard’s educational mission depends on the exploration of challenging ideas. The College has long permitted academic departments to host discussions and debates on difficult topics with speakers who represent a wide range of perspectives and backgrounds. This practice does not constitute institutional endorsement of any external speaker or the viewpoints they express. All speakers, like all members of our community, are expected to comply with our policy on nondiscrimination."

Controversy Explanation: The Naval Academy's history department invited Ben-Ghiat, a history professor at New York University and an expert on authoritarianism, to deliver the Bancroft Memorial Lecture. About a week before Ben-Ghiat's lecture, multiple op-eds opposed her appearance because she was planning to deliver "a partisan screed" --- Ben-Ghiat has previously called former President Trump an "authoritarian" multiple times, but maintains she had no intention of mentioning Trump. A congressman wrote to the Naval Academy's superintendent calling the invitation "a serious lapse in judgment." A day later 4 mmore members of the House of Representatives demanded an explanation for Ben-Ghiat's invitation. The Naval Academy postponed Ben-Ghiat's lecture, and it has yet to be rescheduled.
Public Response: Disingenuous. A Naval Academy representative said that the Bancroft Memorial Lecture series "is currently postponed," that the academy looks forward "to continuing our tradition of facilitating academic discussions centered on open, honest, and relevant topics for our students," and that "he Naval Academy encourages Midshipmen to be critical thinkers who can analyze issues from multiple perspectives and contexts. Our focus is on how to think, not what to think."

Controversy Explanation: The Whig-Cliophilic Society invited Isgur (and co-host David French) to record an espidode of the Advisory Opinions podcast on campus. Whig-Clio was not allowed to host the event on campus, allegedly because of administrator concerns that hosting Isgur (and French) would violate IRS rules for tax-exempt institutions participating in political advocacy. The podcast was recorded off-campus in the local public library. A Princeton administrator later clarified that the event was rejected because student organizations are prvented from hosting events with non-university organizations, and not over concerns about the university's tax status.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: The Whig-Cliophilic Society invited French (and co-host Sarah Isgur) to record an espidode of the Advisory Opinions podcast on campus. Whig-Clio was not allowed to host the event on campus, allegedly because of administrator concerns that hosting French (and Isgur) would violate IRS rules for tax-exempt institutions participating in political advocacy. The podcast was recorded off-campus in the local public library. A Princeton administrator later clarified that the event was rejected because student organizations are prvented from hosting events with non-university organizations, and not over concerns about the university's tax status.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: Faculty members in the university's English department invited Butler and other Palestinian activisits (Saree Makdisi, Umayyah Cable, Abi Fletcher, Plestia Alaqad, and Ranna Abduljawad) for a two-day symposium titled "Critical Conversations in the Humanities: The War in Israel/Palestine." Less than 24 hours before the event was scheduled to begin, university administrators withdrew support citing policy violations in how the faculty organizers promoted the event. The faculty, who alleged that the cancellation constituted viewpoint discrimination, moved the event off-campus to a local church where it occurred successfully.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: Faculty members in the university's English department invited Makdisi and other Palestinian activisits (Judith Butler, Umayyah Cable, Abi Fletcher, Plestia Alaqad, and Ranna Abduljawad) for a two-day symposium titled "Critical Conversations in the Humanities: The War in Israel/Palestine." Controversy Explanation: Lindsay appeared on a panel (with Bobbie Anne Cox and Gina Arena) on “Saving Women’s Sports," sponsored by the campus chapter of the Federalist Society and moderated by David Skjerli and Houston Porter. The event began civily with 45 minutes of discussion, but during the Q&A students and faculty began yelling at the panelists. One faculty member allegedly rushed the stage. Security escorted panelists out and the event concluded early.
Public Response: None.

Security escorted panelists out and the event concluded early.

Controversy Explanation: A professor in the department of history invited Shakir, the Director of the Israel and Palestine Country Director at Human Rights Watch, to speak on campus. After Shakir's talk was announced, the executive director of the Baltimore Zionist District called on the members of their organization to "Call the President NOW and demand the event be canceled." Shakir spoke successfully on campus.
Public Response: Neutral. In a statement the unversity president said: "I'm sorry if they feel that way but I think people do have a right to express their point of view whether we agree with or not agree with it. We are a public university, this is a public place and that's important. I myself am of the Jewish faith and of course I take exception to anti-Semitism, it's abhorrent. We certainly aren't condoning hate speech and hateful kinds of things being said."

Controversy Explanation: Wax, a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania, was invited to appear on “The World According to Bob and Andy,” a weekly radio show on the university's student-run radio station. Ten minutes before Wax's appearance the hosts were informed that the radio station's E-Board had voted to cancel the interview because "the proposed interview did not meet [the] station’s goals of providing content by and for Binghamton students and community members.” Wax did not appear and the hosts discussed the upcoming presidential election and censorship on college campuses instead.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: Students, a faculty member, and staff organized a screening of the film to be followed by a panel discussion moderated by Yannik Thiem and featuring Nadia Saah, Helga Tawil-Souri, Rachel Kahn-Troster, and Simone Zimmerman. A few weeks before the screening and panel were scheduled to take place, the college's president asked the faculty member helping organizing the event to "pause the film" over concerns that the film is "antisemitic" and that the college could be facing a Title VI investigation. When the faculty member decided to hold the panel without screening the film, the college informed he she could screen the film but also asked her to "ensure that audience reactions and the ensuing panel discussion will remain respectful and inclusive at all times and devoid of any discrimination or hate speech." The film was screened and the panel was held successfully.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  A college spokesperson said that the film screening and panel ultimately "took place in February, consistent with our longstanding practice of allowing professors and academic departments to host events that represent a wide range of perspectives."

Controversy Explanation: Zimmerman was scheduled to appear on a panel (along with Nadia Saah, Helga Tawil-Souri, and Rachel Kahn-Troster, with Yannik Thiem as the moderator) after a screening of the film Israelism. A few weeks before the screening and panel were scheduled to take place, the college's president asked the faculty member helping organizing the event to "pause the film" over concerns that the film is "antisemitic" and that the college could be facing a Title VI investigation. When the faculty member decided to hold the panel without screening the film, the college informed he she could screen the film but also asked her to "ensure that audience reactions and the ensuing panel discussion will remain respectful and inclusive at all times and devoid of any discrimination or hate speech." Public Response: Disingenuous. A college spokesperson said that the film screening and panel ultimately "took place in February, consistent with our longstanding practice of allowing professors and academic departments to host events that represent a wide range of perspectives."

The film was screened and the panel was held successfully.

Controversy Explanation: Thiem was scheduled to moderate a panel (featuring Nadia Saah, Helga Tawil-Souri, Rachel Kahn-Troster, and Simone Zimmerman) after a screening of the film Israelism. A few weeks before the screening and panel were scheduled to take place, the college's president asked the faculty member helping organizing the event to "pause the film" over concerns that the film is "antisemitic" and that the college could be facing a Title VI investigation. When the faculty member decided to hold the panel without screening the film, the college informed he she could screen the film but also asked her to "ensure that audience reactions and the ensuing panel discussion will remain respectful and inclusive at all times and devoid of any discrimination or hate speech." The film was screened and the panel was held successfully.
Public Response: Disingenuous. A college spokesperson said that the film screening and panel ultimately "took place in February, consistent with our longstanding practice of allowing professors and academic departments to host events that represent a wide range of perspectives."

Controversy Explanation: Hammer's debate with Professor John Dehn was interrupted by pro-Palestinian protesters affiliated with the campus’s Students for Justice in Palestine (SJP) chapter. Hammer, who planned to speak about presidential immunity, was met with disruptive actions and personal accusations by attendees. After Hammer made a remark about needing to take the "trash" out and told the protesters that he "hope[d] their beepers don't go off," Dehn ended the event prematurely. Hammer later described the experience on X as harassment based on his Jewish identity and pro-Israel stance.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: A member of Congress, multiple state senators, members of the general public, and students at the university objected to the FL3TCHER EXHIBIT at the university's Reece Museum for featuring Evolution (and other artwork), a "hateful" and "divisve" piece of art. Evolution features Speaker of the House Mike Johnson in front of a swastika morphing into a cross. In response the university asked visitors to sign a liability waiver before entering the exhibit, and added curtains and content warnings to the exhibit.
Public Response: Condemned Expression.  In a statement the university president said: "I am aware of the concerns that have been raised about works selected to appear in this year’s FL3TCHER EXHIBIT on display in the Reece Museum. As a Christian and the son of a veteran, I can say that I personally find some of the views expressed in this year’s exhibit abhorrent. However, as the president of a public university, which is bound by the laws of the State of Tennessee as well as the U.S. Constitution, I must ensure that our university adheres to state and federal law. I am working to gain more information, and we will undertake an examination of the process through which we allow guest artists, speakers, and other third-party groups to present information on campus."

Controversy Explanation: A member of Congress, multiple state senators, members of the general public, and students at the university objected to the FL3TCHER EXHIBIT at the university's Reece Museum for featuring Patriot (and other artwork), a "hateful" and "divisve" piece of art. Patriot features an American flag made from a Ku Klux Klan hood. In response the university asked visitors to sign a liability waiver before entering the exhibit, and added curtains and content warnings to the exhibit.
Public Response: Condemned Expression.  In a statement the university president said: "After consultation with legal counsel, I cannot, in good faith, censor this exhibit because doing so would run counter to the duties of the Office of the President to uphold the laws of the State of Tennessee. The exhibit will be partitioned off with warning signs posted that note its handling of disturbing, divisive, sensitive, and mature subjects. Individuals will be allowed to observe the exhibit only after reviewing and signing a waiver. The divisive and hateful messages and images present in this exhibit run counter to [the university’s] values, and I personally find some of the ideas expressed to be deeply offensive and simply despicable."

Controversy Explanation: A member of Congress, multiple state senators, members of the general public, and students at the university objected to the FL3TCHER EXHIBIT at the university's Reece Museum for featuring It's All Connected (and other artwork), a "hateful" and "divisve" piece of art. It's All Connected is a collage that features "violent" messaages from members of the alt-right. In response the university asked visitors to sign a liability waiver before entering the exhibit, and added curtains and content warnings to the exhibit.
Public Response: Condemned Expression.  In a statement the university president said: "After consultation with legal counsel, I cannot, in good faith, censor this exhibit because doing so would run counter to the duties of the Office of the President to uphold the laws of the State of Tennessee. The exhibit will be partitioned off with warning signs posted that note its handling of disturbing, divisive, sensitive, and mature subjects. Individuals will be allowed to observe the exhibit only after reviewing and signing a waiver. The divisive and hateful messages and images present in this exhibit run counter to [the university’s] values, and I personally find some of the ideas expressed to be deeply offensive and simply despicable."

Controversy Explanation: Dollinger, a professor of Jewish history at San Francisco State University, was inviggted by the university's Judaic Studies Department to talk about his book "Black Power, Jewish Politics," that analyzes the relationship between Jewish and Black political activism during the Civil Rights Movement. During Dollinger's talk, masked students began shouting "Dolling, you can't hide!" and  "Zionism is a crime!" A faculty member attempted to engage with the protesters and campus police were called. The protesters left before campus polce arrived and Dollinger resumed his talk and completed it.
Public Response: Honors.  In an official statement the university administration said: "On November 19, a group of face-masked individuals attempted to shout down a speaker invited to the University of Michigan by the Frankel Center for Judicial Studies. Though the talk did not include a pro-Israel message nor did it involve controversial issues related to the crisis in the Middle East, the event was disrupted by individuals who shouted “You can’t hide, Zionism is a crime,” and “We don’t do dialogue with Zionists. Get off our campus.” The speaker is Jewish and was discussing the history of Jews. Shouting down speakers for any reason is unacceptable at the University of Michigan. It violates our academic mission and our commitment to free speech and diversity of thought. Doing so in a way that, in this case, targeted a person because of their Jewish identity is particularly abhorrent and will not be tolerated. The university condemns all forms of discrimination, racism and bias in the strongest possible terms. The actions of the individuals who interrupted this event are a clear instance of antisemitism. The university is working to identify the perpetrators so they can be held accountable."

Controversy Explanation: A graduating senior launched a Change.org petition calling on the university to remove Rooted, an outdoor art installation, becasuse it "is obstructing the natural beauty of our campus and ruining our photos." The petition garnered over 1,800 signatures and the Student Government Association voted to remove Rooted and called on the university to consult with students about any future public art projects. The university has not removed the art installation.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Topic(s): Gender, Immigration, Political Views, Race, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Morgan, the executive vice president of the Heritage Foundation and an alumnus of the university, was invited by the School of Economic, Political, and Policy Sciences to discuss the results of the 2024 presidential election. Multiple student groups, including Texas Rising and the Young Democratice Socials of America, objected to Morgan's invitation because of his involvement with Project 2025 and his views on transgender rights, and mounted an email campaign to get the talk canceled. Morgan spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral.  A university spokesperson said: "We recognize that our community is diverse and holds varying viewpoints. UT Dallas remains committed to fostering an environment that promotes civil discourse, and we encourage our students to respectfully engage with those who hold different perspectives."

Speaker/Performer/Title: Queers Demand Justice: A Saftey Spell for Queer Palestinians
Controversy Explanation: A state senator held up the university's ability to borrow money to construct a new facility on campus that would house the university's TV and radio stations, and to rennovate part of a health science building because he considered the painting, Queers Demand Justice: A Saftey Spell for Queer Palestinians, offensive and demanded the university remove the painting. The university refused and the exhibit closed at the end of the week.
Public Response: None.
